Incredible when you think that the biggest news was supposed to be about Halo and the new console Project Scarlett, which achieved 33% of the vote.

JP11:18am

Each AAA product launched by CD Projekt has seen exponential growth versus the previous title, not just an incremental increase. The launch quarter for Witcher 3 compared to the combined two launch quarters (one on PC, one on Xbox 360) for Witcher 2 resulted in a 321% uplift in copies sold, 658% increase in title revenues, and 760% growth in net profit. We expect Cyberpunk to be an extremely ambitious franchise and that a multi release strategy will drive the year two revenue surprise to the upside. We are not talking about the option to release two expansion packs, DLCs, to extend the base affect or monetise existing players but more the second stage launch of game format. By this we mean multiplayer. A game designed for multiplayer environments can enjoy increasing DAUs, recurring revenues and new players. There are two reasons why World of Warcraft became so successful in the multiplayer world. 1. It was the first to market in its genre. WoW was the first MMO to reach scale.

2. Despite growing competition it managed to remain on top by introducing a unique identity and the ability to make changes. The identity is what makes one person’s game different from another’s and that can be around the actual game player, the atmosphere, the mechanics, the unique individual character customisations etc. And then to keep the gamers active and involved introduce new content and additional objectives on a regular [but not too aggressively] basis.

JP11:19am

JP11:19am

We have three CP2077 unit assumptions. Our low case has 28m units for 2020, our base case has 33m for 2020 and our high scenario is set at 50m units. We have adjusted our model accordingly. See chart below. Our 2020 revenue assumption is now (on the base case scenario) at PLN4.775B which is 68% above consensus. This drives operating profit of PLN2.77B which is 48% above consensus estimate of PLN 1.87B.

BE11:20am

Cyberpunk 2077 launches on April 16, 2020 and features Keanu Reeves. Today at Xbox E3 2019 Conference CD Projekt has revealed a new cinematic trailer for Cyberpunk 2077 and confirmed the release date for April 16, 2020. The biggest surprise of the presentation was an appearance of Keanu Reeves, who will be featured in the game. The release date is within consensus expectations. Today at Xbox E3 2019 Conference CD Projekt has revealed a new cinematic trailer for Cyberpunk 2077 and confirmed the release date for April 16, 2020. Though we assumed the release in Q4'19, we wrote (here: The "Wild Hunt" into E3) that this assumption received the most pushback upon our initiation, with buy-side expectations geared towards a release in Q2'20. Given consensus expectations, we believe that today’s announcement will be well received by the market and is supportive of our Overweight rating.Q2’2020 is an attractive release window. Some could argue that Q2’20 is a not a typical quarter for the release of a highly anticipated AAA game - it is a smaller revenue pool quarter for the video game industry than “holidays” quarters (Q4/Q1). For example, according to market research firm NPD, an average 55% of United States video game hardware and software retail spending happens between September and December. However, 1) we would argue that this logic is more applicable to indie BBB quality titles, and for a game of Cyberpunk 2077's size and ambition a release quarter matters less, as audience will follow. 2) Furthermore, we believe that Q2 2020 is a very attractive release window given the absence of other big titles and it would make robust commercial sense for CDR to pursue a release when gamers' attention is undivided. 3) Cyberpunk will be released on the current generation of console, but close enough to be ported over to the next generation (Expected Q4’20), which implies potentially higher installment base (if the game is good and demand is there). Cyberpunk will feature Keanu Reeves. The biggest surprise of the presentation (that we attended in person) was an appearance of Keanu Reeves at end of the trailer, and then on stage, where he announced the game’s release date. “The trailer reveals one of the key characters of Cyberpunk 2077, Johnny Silverhand. The legendary rockerboy is played by Hollywood actor Keanu Reeves (The Matrix trilogy, John Wick series, Johnny Mnemonic). In addition to his appearance and voice, Reeves is also providing full-body motion capture for the character”, the Company’s press release states. Ad oculos, an appearance of a famous actor of such profile in the video game could significantly increase its popularity and sales potential. Cyberpunk 2077 is available for pre-orders: Cyberpunk 2077 Standard edition will be priced at $60€60, which is in-line with market prices and our estimates. A potential source of upside could come from the game’s Collector’s Edition, which is priced at $245/€245, and included a number of collectibles (eg. a statue depicting the game’s protagonist).

BE11:31am

This is a repeat of a similar
story in late April and it is not a surprise that Fosun has ongoing aspirations to own
this part of the business. As previously discussed it is unlikely that Fosun would be
able to buy the group in its current form as non-EU entities are restricted in owning
a European airline.
The group is currently in the process of trying to sell its airline which could free the
way for Fosun to acquire the residual business. It seems that Fosun does not want
to wait to acquire the listed entity or indeed that it fears unforeseen consequences
in any restructuring/recapitalisation process (eg Triton’s confirmed interest in the
Northern European business). We suspect this comes from a desire to own the tour
operating business and support its long term future but ideally without paying a
premium for the listed entity.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Although the group has re-organized itself to enable the disposal of the airline we
do not think that selling the core tour operation out of the corporate structure will be
simple. The group still has £1bn of outstanding bonds as well as drawings on its bank
facilities and commercial paper which are supported by the tour operating business.
Bond holder and lender consents would likely be required which may make any
disposal impractical unless alternative security or repayment at par was offered.
Under the current capital structure we continue to see no value for current
shareholders unless Fosun pays a very high price for the tour operator and/or the
group is able to sell its airline at a much higher than expected value (Citi valuation
£600m). Our SOTP target price is 0p (Bull case 27p) per share and within this we
value the Tour operator at 4x FY19 EBIT compared to an historic trading range for
listed tour operators of 4-8x. We estimate that each turn on the tour operator
valuation multiple equates to 4-5p per share suggesting that the current share price
is either valuing the tour operator at closer to a peak multiple or it could imply a
valuation for the airline of around £850m (7x FY19 EBIT). We think a
recapitalization of the business is required.

Since Thomas Cook announced the strategic review of the Airline division in Feb-19, various headlines and speculation have been circling about preliminary bids for all or parts of the Group, (see TCG - Weekend press: Bidders circling Thomas Cook (23/4/19)) including Fosun for the Tour Op or entire business. The company confirmed with H1 19 results that it had ‘received multiple bids, including for the whole, or parts, of the airline business.’ However, uncertainty has remained on a number of topics e.g. whether the Airline could be sold in full or in part, the value of a potential sale, who the acquirers may be and the tour op-airline relationship post-sale. These factors will define the shape of the remaining business and while they are unknown, the Tour Op’s future remains unsure. Therefore, the weekend news reduces that uncertainty, particularly given it is not yet clear whether debt will be sufficiently reduced by a sale of the airline for the remaining business to comfortably meet financing requirements in the medium-to-long term. The shares remain cheap, trading on 2.2x cal19E P/E, 1.8x EV/EBITDA, 34.2% Equity FCF Yield.

BE11:48am

The process of industrializing capital allocation at insurers has not yet been rewarded but is fully underway. This should lead to less earnings volatility, sharper operational focus and better cash management. As improved track records emerge so the cost of equity for the sector should fall. In this report we develop a RoRAC view of returns and compare this with IFRS ROCEs. We make multiple (positive) recommendation changes and outline a new framework for considering upside potential.

Bluesky21 Is L&G not just a massive bet that people won't live as long as we currently think they will?
11:48 am
BE11:48am

The Nordic and Reinsurers have been rewarded in recent years through a lower cost of capital, driven in part by stable ROEs and high payout ratios. The benefits from integrated capital management tools, including economic returns, can improve the track records of the multi-lines in particular leading to less volatility, increased IFRS ROEs and higher payouts. We are now buyers of 4 of the 5 multi-lines partly as a result.

BE11:49am

Allianz, L&G and Prudential screen well on ROCE and RoRAC. Zurich and RSA are improving RoRACs while also reducing earnings volatility which characterized a previous era. AXA and Aviva will be incentivized to manage a growing capital base to improve returns. All companies are prioritizing strategic investments that strengthen competitive positioning. Delivery of the benefits from efficient capital allocation is still to earn through. Reinsurers frustrate through the insistence on holding excess capital as an option on a sharp cycle turn, when this optionality has reduced.

Tom Dalgleish "industrialising capital allocation" means what
BE11:49am

We upgrade Allianz, Prudential and RSA to Buy from Neutral. We also replace Aviva with AXA on the Citi European Focus List. Generali and Aegon are both moved to Neutral from Sells. L&G and Zurich stay as Buys. Our top three picks are now AXA, Allianz and L&G. Key Sells are Munich Re and Hannover Re.

BE11:50am

In this report we seek insight into how companies are benefiting from the integrated use of capital management tools that probably started in earnest 2-3 years ago. We say "integrated" because economic capital models have been in use for some time but it is only relatively recently that companies have learned to balance financial, economic and cash metrics. The potential benefits are significant with reduced earnings volatility, higher ROEs and bigger payouts all possible.

Bluesky21 The use of AI to improve underwriting, I suspect, requires a series of iterative improvements based on data. So more applicable to property & casualty part of insurance, not life

11:50 am

Insurers have been running economic capital models for some time but it is only over the last 2-3 years that we've seen more sophisticated implementation that integrates economic returns, accounting returns and cash metrics. This is a new paradigm that is seeing the industrialization of a scarce resource to drive value.

Overlap and approvals. We see few areas of overlap here, though some products in Raytheon SAS and the Defense business of Rockwell Collins might present market concentration issues. We don’t see these being meaningful though. We think DoD is sensitive to contractors amassing significant power but
on the military side, Raytheon Technologies will still be significantly smaller than Lockheed and doesn’t really become any more dominant in specific areas than either company was independently. Chinese approval would obviously be an issue if required but we assume it will not be, since it seems unlikely that Raytheon sells anything there.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

The fact that UTC is an interested buyer of a less-cyclical, defense-focused
asset like Raytheon is not really a surprise given the company’s recent reorganization and longer-term
uncertainty facing its commercial aerospace portfolio from Boeing’s aspirations to grow its commercial
services business. It’s less clear to us what’s in the deal for Raytheon as it strikes us as being the superior
asset in the combination. In other words, we’d rather own a defense business with 12.2% margins and a
10% FCF yield than a more commercial-focused business with 12.9% margins and 7% FCF yield.
The strategic rationale behind the transaction appears focused on (1) durability / lessening cyclicality and (2)
the various benefits of scale. We had never viewed Raytheon as being disadvantaged because of its scale
and UTC’s business is more cyclical than Raytheon’s, so - again - the rationale seems to address UTC’s
needs more than Raytheon’s, unless this was also about simply finding the best partner in a consolidating
space. A scenario whereby Raytheon would be competing longer-term against Lockheed Martin and a
combined Northrop + UTC may have been an unacceptable outcome of consolidation for Raytheon and
made its combination with UTC more appealing.
The current bear thesis on Raytheon is that Patriot will eventually be replaced and the company is not well
positioned to win the follow-on, threatening Raytheon’s core portfolio. If that threat is more real than we had
perceived it to be, then the UTC deal makes sense.

BE12:01pm

Expected Financials Seem Reasonable, Not Overly Compelling - The transaction is expected to
generate ~$1B in cost synergies with roughly half of the synergies being returned to customers. In our view,
the $1B cost synergies target seems low and the portion expected to be returned to customers seems high.
The $1B in expected cost synergies would represent 3.4% of Raytheon-standalone’s sales which is well
below the cost synergies realized from UTC’s most recent transactions involving Goodrich (7% of sales)
and Rockwell Collins (7% of sales). Further, Raytheon Technologies is expected to be 54% defense / 46%
commercial in pro-forma sales, so giving back 50% of the cost synergies to the customer seems really high.
The typical rule of thumb is the % of cost synergies passed back to the customer equals the portion of costplus
revenue in the business. Given the current political backdrop, erring on the side of conservatism in both
cases make sense, but $500m in net cost synergies on combined revenue of ~$74B offers only modest
margin expansion potential when considering the likelihood that R&D may also be increasing.

BE12:13pm

Peel Hunt:

12:12 pm
BE12:13pm

Unsurprisingly, the growth rate slowed in Q3 led by softer market conditions in the US as new housing slipped back slightly and commercials markets only grew modestly. The group’s bolt-on acquisitions and organic share gains have helped and overall forecast expectations are unchanged for the full year. Having seen the rating step back from 16-18x PE to c. 13x PE we feel comfortable with our positive recommendation despite the US macro worries.

BE12:13pm

Q3 Update. Q3 saw revenue rise by 6.2% with trading profits up 2.3%. The US posted the bulk of the revenue growth with 8.4% while the UK was +0.4% and Canada was +2.9%. Like for like revenue in the US however tailed off to +3.3% from +9.7% in Q2 on the back of a slower market place with saw new residential activity decline modestly while commercial was up only slightly. The group's order book point to modest growth in the final quarter.
UK lfl revenue was +2.8% and while gross margins eased again cost control left profits flat yr on yr. Canada struggled from softer residential markets which left lfl revenue down 2.9% and profits flat. Ongoing robust cash generation has left the group sitting on excess cash and as a result the business is announcing a new $500m buy back which will be carried out over the coming 12 months.
Forecasts & Outlook. The group is sticking to previous guidance in terms of profits for the full year so we expect to see limited changes to estimates. Revenue growth is expected to be in the modest single digits with market growth of 1-2% being complimented by acquisitions and organic share gains.
Performance & Valuation. The shares have risen 5% ytd but drifted back 3-4% in the last month or so as concerns about the growth rate in the US economy have risen. Our existing forecasts the shares are trading on a 13.0x PE for July 2019 with a 10.0x EV/EBITDA and a 3.0% dividend yield. We think these are attractive valuations given the medium term growth potential that still exists for the group.
